results.title: Heaven
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Surfing, sexuality and masculine bodies beneath the female gaze. A handheld camera closes in on private space of surfers as they disrobe in carparks and attempts to catch them ‘out’. Filmed in and around Sydney beaches, Moffatt and female friends have documented a playful but edgey representation of surfer culture as the interaction between the filmmaker and subject moves towards active voyerism. The heavy drum beats and lapping waves of the soundtrack mirror the thrill and excitement of gender mis-representation. How do the males react, or perform, on camera and how do audiences interpret their own voyeuristic desires? What does it suggest about the role of the film maker, of ethics or ‘surveillance’?

constellations_other.name: Flipping the gaze (Placeholder)
constellations_other.description: Steven Rhall's Avert considers how the white gaze has been trained on First Peoples and flips the surveillance by turning the camera on the viewer.

results.title: New life new country
results.creator_credit: Fatma Coskun, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Fatma Coskun came from a small village amongst the mountains of Corun. However, financial hardships drove her and her husband to Australia to start a new life. Despite a major setback at the beginning of their journey, Fatma and her family consider themselves very fortunate to have settled in Australia.

results.title: The Way things go
results.creator_credit: David Weiss, Peter Fischli, Mirjam Krakenberger and Rainer Trinkler
results.brief_description: Inside a warehouse, artists Peter Fischli and David Weiss build an enormous, precarious structure 100 feet long made out of common household items - tea kettles, tires, old shoes, balloons, wooden ramps, etc. Then, with fire, water, gravity, and chemistry, they create a spectacular chain reaction, a self destructing performance of physical interactions, chemical reactions, and precisely-crafted chaos worthy of Rube Goldberg or Alfred Hitchcock.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Weiss, Peter Fischli, Mirjam Krakenberger and Rainer Trinkler

results.title: Pulse
results.brief_description: A series of silent epiphanies of night-time Melbourne. Young Melbourne filmmaker, Emma Sleath, has proposed a poignant and haunting series of tableaus for the ‘public imaging’ zones of the ground floor of ACMI.

results.title: Lost book found
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: The result of over five years of Super 8 and 16mm filming on New York City streets, ‘Lost Book Found’ melds documentary and narrative approaches into a complex meditation on city life. The piece revolves around a mysterious notebook filled with obsessive listings of places, objects, and incidents which serve as the key to a hidden city. It is a city on unconsidered geographies and layered artefacts - the relics of low-level capitalism and the debris of countless forgotten narratives. The project stems from the filmmaker’s first job in New York - working as a pushcart vendor on Canal Street. As usual, Cohen shot in hundreds of locations using unobtrusive equipment and generally without any crew. Influenced by the work of Walter Benjamin, Cohen created ‘an archive of undirected shots and sounds, then set out to explore the boundary’ between genres. During the process Cohen said, ‘I found connections between the street vendor, Benjamin’s ‘flaneur’ and my own work as an observer and collector of ephemeral street life’.
